economic_context.details: Multiple disputes over compensation for animals that died under Colas's care as herdsman. Estienne Cherrier owed Colas 80 francs and sold him vineyard for 85 francs to settle debt. Dispute over cow compensation with Lorentz Blosson led to court case. Dispute with Chrestien le Clerc over cow killed by wolf led to appeal to kreutzgang and 15 francs payment. Adam Marchal threatened to burn Colas if he bought house/garden being sold for debt. Economic hardship evident - Colas said he was too poor to pay for wine.

extraction_metadata.notes: Detailed trial with extensive witness testimony, complex legal proceedings including torture, retraction, and renewed confession. Multiple economic disputes and quarrels over animal compensation. Notable for confession involving accomplice Mayette, powder from stillborn child, sabbat attendance, and devil named Joly. Trial demonstrates pattern of accusations following quarrels and animal deaths. Colas repeatedly called witch publicly but never sought legal redress. Extensive detail on folk prayers and protective rituals used by herdsmen.
